document_title: Indian Emergency Response System - Fire Emergency SOPs

system_metadata.jurisdiction: Republic of India - All States and Union Territories

P1_CRITICAL.label: Critical - Life Threatening
P1_CRITICAL.description: Immediate threat to life or major property. Highest resource priority. Multi-agency response.
criteria: Persons trapped or in immediate danger

P2_URGENT.label: Urgent - Serious
P2_URGENT.description: Serious situation requiring prompt response but not immediately life-threatening

P3_PRIORITY.label: Priority - Non-Emergency Urgent
P3_PRIORITY.description: Important but not critical, can be scheduled without immediate danger

P4_ROUTINE.label: Routine - Non-Urgent
P4_ROUTINE.description: Non-emergency routine services and administrative matters

fire_emergency_sops.title: Residential Building Fire

assign_P1_if: LPG cylinder explosion reported or imminent
Fire spreading rapidly to adjacent structures
assign_P2_if: Ground or first floor fire with occupants safely evacuated
Electrical fire with power not yet cut off
Heavy smoke but no visible flames
assign_P3_if: Small kitchen fire contained to single room
Fire contained and controlled by occupants
Minor electrical short circuit without flames

P1_resources: 2-3 Fire tenders minimum (1 water tender + 1 ladder tender)
Advanced Life Support ambulance with paramedics
Police team for crowd control and area security
P2_resources: Basic Life Support ambulance on standby
Police patrol vehicle for traffic management

critical_questions: Exact location with landmark (street name, building name, flat number)
Are people trapped? If yes, how many and where?
Nearby hazards (petrol pump, hospital, school, factory)
dispatcher_actions: Start call timer for response tracking
Activate location services/GPS if mobile call
Keep caller on line for updates

dispatch_sequence: Alert nearest fire station - dispatch appropriate units per priority
Notify police control room for traffic clearance and crowd control
Alert ambulance service (dispatch immediately for P1, standby for P2)
If slum fire - immediately request 2-3 additional fire tenders
Notify senior fire officer if P1 incident
Alert electricity board for power cutoff
response_protocol_steps.communication_protocol: Use standardized fire dispatch codes. Provide: Location, Type of fire, Priority level, Trapped persons status, Special hazards

critical_instructions: EVACUATE IMMEDIATELY - Do not stop to collect belongings
STAY LOW - Smoke rises, breathe near floor level
CLOSE DOORS - Close doors behind you to slow fire spread
NO ELEVATORS - Use stairs only, elevators may trap you
ALERT NEIGHBORS - Knock on doors, shout 'Fire! Get Out!'
WET CLOTH - Use wet cloth over nose and mouth if smoky
FEEL DOORS - Before opening, feel door for heat. If hot, use alternate route
IF TRAPPED - Close door, seal gaps with wet towels, go to window, signal for help
response_protocol_steps.keep_caller_calm: Reassure that help is on the way. Fire brigade dispatched. Stay on line for updates.

coordination_tasks: Notify electricity board (BESCOM/MSEB/DVVNL/local utility) for emergency power cutoff
Alert water supply department if additional water source needed
Contact traffic police for route clearance - activate green corridor if P1
If narrow lanes (old city/slum) - request smaller Quick Response Vehicle
Update responding units with real-time information from caller
Prepare for specific hazards (LPG cylinders common in Indian homes)

first_unit_responsibilities: Station Officer assumes Incident Commander role
Size-up: 360-degree assessment of building and fire
Establish command post at safe location (upwind, 100m for P1)
Set up perimeter (100m for P1, 50m for P2) - request police assistance
Conduct primary search for trapped persons - highest priority
Assign entry team with SCBA for interior attack

tactical_approach: Attack from UPWIND side when possible
Use appropriate extinguishing agent based on fire class:
- Water for Class A (wood, paper, cloth)
- Dry powder for Class D (metal fires)
Prevent fire spread to adjacent structures - protect exposures
Ventilate smoke safely from opposite side of attack
COOL LPG cylinders with water spray from safe distance - DO NOT APPROACH if heated/hissing
Check ceiling, loft, and concealed spaces - fire travels upward
response_protocol_steps.indian_context: LPG cylinders (14.2kg) are present in nearly every Indian household - priority is to locate and cool them to prevent explosion

search_protocol: Primary search - rapid sweep of all rooms immediately
Secondary search - thorough search after initial knockdown
Check under beds, in cupboards, bathrooms (children often hide)
Use thermal imaging camera if available
Mark searched rooms with standard symbols
Firefighter carry techniques for victim removal
Immediate oxygen administration to rescued victims
response_protocol_steps.victim_priorities: Children and elderly first, then other adults. All smoke inhalation victims need hospital evaluation.

triage_system: Immediate (RED): Smoke inhalation with respiratory distress, severe burns >20% TBSA, unconscious
Delayed (YELLOW): Moderate burns 10-20%, minor smoke inhalation but alert
Minor (GREEN): Small burns <10%, minor injuries, able to walk
Expectant (BLACK): Deceased or injuries incompatible with life
on_scene_treatment: Smoke inhalation - 100% oxygen via non-rebreather mask
Burns - cool with water for 10-20 minutes (NOT ice)
Cover burns with sterile dressing, DO NOT apply ointments
All smoke inhalation victims to hospital for CO level check and monitoring
response_protocol_steps.transport_priority: Critical patients to burn center if available, otherwise nearest equipped hospital

overhaul_tasks: Ensure complete extinguishment - check all hotspots with thermal camera
Pull down ceiling/wall coverings to expose hidden fire
investigation_protocol: PRESERVE fire origin area - do not disturb evidence
Forensic photography of scene, origin point, and damage pattern
Document: Electrical panels, appliances, potential ignition sources
Check for fire safety violations (blocked exits, illegal storage)
Estimate monetary damage for insurance purposes
Prepare detailed incident report within 24 hours
response_protocol_steps.evidence_preservation: If arson suspected, seal area and notify police immediately. Do not allow re-entry until investigation complete.

escalation_triggers.action: Request additional tenders and manpower from neighboring stations
escalation_triggers.notification: District Fire Officer, Municipal Fire Chief

escalation_triggers.action: Evacuate 200m radius, withdraw all personnel, call structural engineer
escalation_triggers.notification: NDRF, Municipal Corporation, Police for wider evacuation

escalation_triggers.action: Activate Hazmat protocol, evacuate 500m, specialized PPE
escalation_triggers.notification: State Disaster Management, Pollution Control Board, District Magistrate

escalation_triggers.action: Activate Mass Casualty Incident (MCI) protocol, request multiple ambulances
escalation_triggers.notification: Civil Surgeon, Blood Bank, All nearby hospitals

escalation_triggers.action: Priority resource allocation, protect critical facility
Request 5+ fire tenders, bulldozer for firebreak, mass evacuation
escalation_triggers.notification: District Disaster Management, Revenue Department for relief, NGOs for temporary shelter

mandatory_notifications: Local Police Station (for FIR if required - suspected arson)
Electricity Board for emergency power disconnection
Media Cell (if major incident for accurate information dissemination)
conditional_notifications: State Disaster Response Force (SDRF) - if incident beyond local capacity
National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) - if calamity-scale event
Revenue Department - for damage assessment and compensation
Social Welfare Department - for victim rehabilitation and shelter
Indian Air Force - if aerial water dropping required (forest interface fires)
Indian Railways - if fire near railway property or affecting operations
NGOs and Civil Society - for relief supplies if mass displacement
Insurance Companies - through police for investigation and claims

india_specific_considerations.details: 14.2kg domestic LPG cylinders present in nearly every household. Priority action: locate and cool with water spray from safe distance (minimum 10m). If cylinder is heated (bulging, hissing, discolored) - evacuate immediately, do not approach. Explosion risk: BLEVE (Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapor Explosion) can propel cylinder 500m+

Many Indian cities have historic areas with lanes too narrow for standard fire tenders (width <3m). Solution: Use Quick Response Vehicles, motorcycle units, or manual firefighting with portable equipment. Pre-planning essential - identify access points in advance.

Jhuggi-jhopdi clusters (slums) present unique challenges: Extremely rapid fire spread due to kutcha houses (thatch, plastic, wood), very close proximity (<1m spacing), inadequate water supply, no access for vehicles. Fire can destroy 500+ homes in under an hour. Strategy: Aggressive initial attack, create firebreaks, mass evacuation, arrange immediate relief shelters.

India has 22 official languages and hundreds of dialects. Firefighters must know local language (Hindi/Tamil/Bengali/Telugu/Marathi etc.) or have translation support. Use visual communication (hand signals) when language barrier exists. Public safety announcements must be multilingual.

Temples, mosques, churches, gurudwaras require culturally sensitive handling. Coordinate with religious leaders, respect customs (remove shoes in temples, head covering in gurudwaras), preserve religious artifacts if safe to do so. Community cooperation essential.

June-September heavy rains create: Waterlogged streets (pump capacity needed), limited visibility, slippery surfaces, flooding in low-lying areas, difficult access. Ensure pumps rated for muddy water, have backup routes planned.

Indian joint family system means 10-15 people may live in single household. Thorough search absolutely essential - multiple bedrooms, elderly/disabled who may not evacuate, children in various rooms. Account for everyone via resident list.

Mosquito coils (slow-burning, often left overnight), kerosene stoves (leaks common), electrical overload (illegal connections, old wiring), incense sticks and diyas (oil lamps), clothes drying near heat sources, cooking fires (chulha), short circuits during power fluctuations

Mumbai chawls and old buildings in cities: Wooden structures with common corridors, shared toilets, multiple families per floor, rapid vertical fire spread via staircases, poor maintenance. Expect structural weakness, collapse risk.

Diwali: Firecrackers and diyas cause spike in fires (Oct-Nov). Holi: Bonfires. Lohri: Bonfire celebrations (Punjab). Ganesh Visarjan and Durga Puja: Pandal fires. Pre-position resources during festival seasons, public awareness campaigns, ban on crackers in some areas.

tactics: Pressurize stairwells to prevent smoke entry if possible
Helicopter for roof rescue only if safe LZ available

electrical_fires.safety_first: NEVER use water on energized electrical equipment
protocol: Ensure power is cut off - coordinate with electricity board
Use CO2 or dry powder extinguishers
If safe after power cutoff, water can be used
Check electrical panels for main disconnect
Watch for re-energization - power may come back
electrical_fires.common_locations: Electrical rooms, transformer stations, distribution boards, meter rooms, overhead cables

lpg_incidents.recognition: Sweet smell (ethyl mercaptan added for detection), hissing sound, visible vapor
immediate_actions: Do not use electrical switches or mobile phones in gas area
Cool cylinder with water from distance if safe
lpg_incidents.if_fire: Let LPG fire burn if safe - extinguishing may cause gas accumulation and larger explosion. Cool cylinder and surroundings.
lpg_incidents.bleve_signs: Cylinder discoloration (rainbow effect), bulging, loud roaring sound, flames impinging on cylinder. If seen - EVACUATE IMMEDIATELY, withdraw all personnel 500m+

post_incident_requirements: Submit fire investigation report within 72 hours if cause determination needed
Update property owner on building safety status - unsafe buildings must be evacuated and barricaded
Coordinate with insurance surveyors through police
Public information release through authorized spokesperson only
Critique and lessons learned session with all responding units within 7 days
Equipment inspection and refueling - prepare for next call
Counseling support for firefighters if traumatic incident
